message.content:
We must “build up” accounts receivable from the sales that were made on credit (i.e. with the “receive_method” set to Account Receviable) – assuming that there was no beginning AR balance and that no such credit sale has subsequently been collected. In other words, each sale on credit “creates” an increase in receivables. For example, in the sample table the “Sale” transactions with a receive_method of “Account Receviable” are (showing the “after tax” amounts):

• Sale20240105009: 2,49166.72  
• Sale20240107015: 196,387.40  
• Sale20240109020: 25,458.08  
• Sale20240112025: 21,953.76  
• Sale20240117035: 106,371.46  
• Sale20240118039: 313,111.54  
• Sale20240119041: 42,363.05  
• Sale20240120042: 23,649.21  
• Sale20240122045: 560,237.66  
• Sale20240123047: 94,838.12  
• Sale20240123048: 285,572.42  
• Sale20240124050: 569,816.46  
• Sale20240127055: 183,551.11  
• Sale20240128057: 104,809.22

Summing these up step‐by‐step:

 249,166.72 + 196,387.40 = 445,554.12  
 445,554.12 + 25,458.08 = 471,012.20  
 471,012.20 + 21,953.76 = 492,965.96  
 492,965.96 + 106,371.46 = 599,337.42  
 599,337.42 + 313,111.54 = 912,448.96  
 912,448.96 + 42,363.05 = 954,812.01  
 954,812.01 + 23,649.21 = 978,461.22  
 978,461.22 + 560,237.66 = 1,538,698.88  
 1,538,698.88 + 94,838.12 = 1,633,537.00  
 1,633,537.00 + 285,572.42 = 1,919,109.42  
 1,919,109.42 + 569,816.46 = 2,488,925.88  
 2,488,925.88 + 183,551.11 = 2,672,476.99  
 2,672,476.99 + 104,809.22 = 2,777,286.21

Because an increase in accounts receivable represents a use (or “decrease”) of cash, the cash‐flow “effect” is shown with a negative sign.

Thus, the final accounts receivable item (the net change) is –2,777,286.21.

We now present the answer in the required format.

{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable": "-2777286.21"
  }
}
